Award.AwardTitle: Modeling and Simulations of Complex Fluids and Atomistic Strain
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objectives of the project is to build an integrated mathematical and computational research program that includes coherently interconnected mathematical disciplines, targeting, but not limited to, some challenge applications in modeling and simulation of complex fluids and atomic strain. The major goal in the project is to understand the flow instabilities in worm-like micellar fluids such as the oscillating falling sphere and jumping bubbles. Using the three species model that takes into account long and short micelles and the shear-induced structure, the conjectured relation between the flow instability and the shear-induced structures will be investigated. The project will introduce the regularization techniques in the complex-fluid models for robust and stable simulations and will integrate them with a fast multigrid solver in the framework of massively parallel computing techniques. Such integrated modeling and computational method is anticipated to make a rheological modeling software. The project is also aimed at developing the new strain modeling and simulation of nano-crystalline materials. The atomic strain model will be developed by applying the finite element methodology for the continuum linear elasticity. Unlike the conventional strain models developed by using the finite difference approximations, the newly proposed model will mirror and take into account the real atomic structures such as the diamond and zinc structures. The model developed in this project will then be used to investigate a sample strain-related nano-structure formation as its application.

Complex fluids are ubiquitous in nature and industry and they are used in many important areas, including the pharmaceutical, food, military, bio-materials, printing, and oil industry, just to name a few. Strain in nano-crystalline materials is central in materials science research and understanding the strain is critical to provide guidance for the real-life device design applications such as light emitting diodes, injection lasers and solar cells. Yet, the modeling and simulation of complex fluids and strain in nano-crystalline materials remain formidable and grand challenges, even with modern supercomputers. Among others, the inherent deficiency of existing mathematical models and the inefficiency of conventional numerical techniques are the major bottlenecks, which defeat scientists' attempt to understand and design materials. It is anticipated that the modeling and computation methods developed in this research will remedy both the deficiency in the models and the inefficiency in the computation, thereby drastically eliminating the mathematical and computational bottlenecks and eventually providing valuable guiding tools for scientists to better understand the materials of interest within the scope of this project as well as in a number of other neighboring areas of research where the technologies developed in this project can be applied.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A wormlike micellar fluid (WMF) is a fluid composed of tube-like aggregations of surfactant molecules that can break and reform. In a shear flow of WMF, a remarkable effect called shear thickening transition or viscosity enhancement is observed; firstly by Rehage and Hoffmann in 1982. Such a shear thickening transition has then been experimentally proven to be due to the formation of a shear-induced structure or gelation by Liu and Pine in 1996. In recent years, there has been an abundance of interest in material instabilities that can be attributed to such gelation or shear-induced structure. This is because such a gelation can impact many industries related to fluid dynamics, just to cite a few, fire fighting and enhanced oil recovery (EOR). However, mathematical modeling has not been completely understood for gelation-related material instability observed in WMF.

Supported by NSF grant from 2013 to date, the P.I. was able to work on many aspects of modeling, analysis and simulation of WMF. This includes the development of stable numerical schemes for highly elastic fluids flow, the design of a fast solver for the discrete system and a conservative scheme for the Darcy law model. Recently, the P.I. has constructed locally conservative mixed finite elements for axisymmetric Stokes equation. Most importantly, the P.I. has developed a new model of wormlike micellar fluids that takes into account the generation and break of the gelation, i.e., the structural evolution of constituents in WMF and produced successful results for the simple shear flow of WMF. It is well-known that not every WMF can exhibit such shear thickening transition, only ones that contain cylindrical micelles can show such transitions. Using this physical observation, the P.I. introduced a three species model, which takes into account, short micelles (spherical micelles), long micelles (cylindrical or wormlike micelles), and gelation. The model is designed to describe the physical interactions between species, thereby obtaining the first and unique wormlike micellar fluid model that can show the gelation and its effect of shear-banding. The P.I.'s result is shown to agree excellently well with experiments and anticipates to use this result in an important application in industry such as enhanced Oil recovery next.

In summary, the P.I.'s achievement supported by NSF-DMS 1358953: Modeling and Simulations of Complex Fluids and Atomistic Strain. $144,816, total, 07/2013 - 11/30/2018 are as follows:

Intellectual Merit: (1) Shear thickening behavior of wormlike micellar fluids has been mathematically modeled. (2) Fast solver is designed to solve EG-Darcy (3) Modeling of sphere oscillation in WMF is investigated. (4) New stable and conservative mixed finite elements have been analyzed and constructed for axisymmetric Stokes problems. Total 12 papers were completed, 8 appeared in refereed journals and 1 appeared in DreamWorks technical report, (The algorithm, fastccd is being used in DreamWorks). 3 were submitted for publications in 2018.

Broader Impacts: The P.I. has co-organized two workshops, one at AMS meeting in 2014 and the other at SIAM in 2015. The P.I. has delivered a plenary invited talk at the conference, RAACM, Wuhan, China in 2015. The P.I. helped Ph.D. student (Math Education Ph.D. student, C. Starkey) with math research and published a paper at JCM in 2018. Starkey went on to get a faculty job in 2015. Two applied math MS students were advised, one of whom is currently pursuing his Ph.D. at UC at Boulder. Total 9 high school students were mentored through MathWorks program at Texas State University. Two recent high school mentees, J. Shoemaker and E. Nolan have won a Siemens semi-nalist place in the Siemens competition in 2017. The P.I. is currently co-mentering MSEC Ph.D. student, Emad Jafari, who presented a result at ASME in 2018.


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Young-Ju Lee
